options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We covered Italian history from 1945-1980, and the many political, social, and economic changes that occurred during this time. Through this course material, we also focused on improving speaking and writing skills. We were introduced to new vocabulary and gained a deeper understanding of Italian culture.

By the end of this class, I got better at speaking more fluently; at thinking fast on my feet; at holding hard conversations regarding race, immigration, politics. I enriched my vocabulary with every-day idioms/phrases that you do not get to learn in lower level Italian classes. I also learned so much on Italian history and culture since 1943.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: Serena is a great professor, the small class size really allowed for conversation, assigned readings and films are interesting, cool to gain a deep understanding of such a specific historical period
weaknesses: somewhat disorganized

I think this was a very strong class in the sense that it did exactly what it set out to do --teach us Italian in context. We explored different time periods in Italian history and different mediums of transferring knowledge (e.g., we read diary entries from a man who was stuck in Rome during the occupation, we listened to a protest song from the 60s, we watched experimental movies on decolonization, we read an opinion piece written by a famous Italian philosopher, we listened to a podcast about racism in Italy...).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the class was probably as good as an online class can be; the small seminar format was much better than the 15 person seminars I have taken online because it really allowed for conversation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely for students who want to improve their Italian and are interested in history, politics, and culture.

Yes! It was so educational and everyone felt like they improved immensely without even realizing! Serena created a very welcoming and safe space where everyone felt comfortable to speak up regardless of language level. If you want to put the language you are learning in its modern context and to appreciate it even more (which you SHOULD), definitely take this class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
